name: Inguinal Hernia
checklist:
1. Inspection (Standing)

  • Exposure: From umbilicus to mid-thigh.
  • Observe: Note any lump, scars, or skin changes.
  • Cough Impulse: Ask patient to turn head away and cough. Look for an expansile impulse.

2. Palpation (Standing)

  • Get Above: Can you palpate the upper border? (If yes = Scrotal lump; If no = Hernia).
  • Cough Impulse: Feel for impulse.
  • Reducibility: Ask patient to reduce it. If difficult, lie them down.
  • Deep Ring Test: Reduce hernia. Occlude deep ring (mid-point of inguinal ligament, 1.5cm above femoral pulse). Ask to cough.
    • Controlled: Indirect Inguinal Hernia.
    • Reappears: Direct Inguinal Hernia.

3. Palpation (Lying)

  • Confirm: Deep ring test again if unsure.
  • Scrotum: Palpate testes (rule out tumor/hydrocele).

4. Conclusion

  • "I would like to examine the contralateral groin and perform a respiratory exam."
findings:
Common Findings
  • Indirect: Reducing towards the flank (lateral). Controlled by deep ring pressure. Reaches scrotum.
  • Direct: Reducing straight back (posterior). Not controlled by deep ring pressure. Rarely scrotal.
  • Femoral: Below and lateral to pubic tubercle. Hard, non-compressible.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Anatomy: The inguinal canal contains the spermatic cord (men) or round ligament (women) + ilioinguinal nerve.
Boundaries:
- Floor: Inguinal ligament.
- Roof: Conjoint tendon.
- Posterior: Transversalis fascia.
- Anterior: External oblique aponeurosis.
Management: Symptomatic hernias require mesh repair (Lichtenstein or Laparoscopic). Strangulated hernias are surgical emergencies.

name: Thyroid Status
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Water: Give patient a glass of water.
  • Observation: Look for goiter, scars, dilated veins.
  • Swallow: Ask to swallow. (Thyroid moves up).
  • Tongue: Protrude tongue. (Thyroglossal cyst moves up).

2. Palpation (From Behind)

  • Thyroid: Palpate lobes and isthmus. Assess size, consistency, and nodules.
  • Swallow: Palpate while patient swallows.
  • Lymph Nodes: Cervical chain (Level I-VI).
  • Trachea: Check for deviation.

3. Percussion & Auscultation

  • Percuss: Manubrium (Retrosternal extension).
  • Auscultate: Thyroid lobes for bruit (Graves').

4. Systemic Check

  • Hands: Tremor (paper test), Pulse (AF/Tachy), Palms (sweaty/erythema).
  • Eyes: Exophthalmos, Lid lag (Graves'), Ophthalmoplegia (H-test).
  • Reflexes: Biceps reflex (Hyper/Hypo).
  • Legs: Pretibial myxedema.
findings:
Significance
  • Graves' Disease: Diffuse smooth goiter + Bruit + Eye signs + Pretibial myxedema.
  • Multinodular Goiter: Irregular, nodular surface. Usually euthyroid.
  • Malignancy: Hard, fixed nodule. Hoarse voice (RLN palsy). Cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Hashimoto's: Firm, rubbery, diffuse goiter. Hypothyroid.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Solitary Nodule Management: TSH -> USG -> FNAC.
Complications of Thyroidectomy:
1. Hematoma (Airway compromise - remove sutures immediately).
2. Hypocalcemia (Parathyroid injury).
3. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve injury (Hoarseness).
4. Thyroid Storm.

name: Varicose Veins
checklist:
1. Inspection (Standing)

  • Look: Long Saphenous (medial) vs Short Saphenous (posterior calf).
  • Skin Changes: Venous eczema, Lipodermatosclerosis (champagne bottle leg), Atrophie blanche, Ulcers (gaiter area).
  • Scars: Previous harvest or surgery.

2. Palpation

  • Temperature: Warmth (phlebitis/cellulitis).
  • Tenderness: Along the vein.
  • Pit Test: Cough impulse at Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ).

3. Special Tests

  • Tap Test: Tap SFJ, feel wave distally (Valvular incompetence).
  • Trendelenburg Test: Lie down -> Elevate leg (empty veins) -> Occlude SFJ -> Stand up.
    • Fills rapidly before release: Perforator incompetence.
    • Fills rapidly only after release: SFJ incompetence.
  • Perthes Test: Tourniquet + Heel raise exercise. (Pain = Deep vein occlusion).

4. Auscultation

  • Doppler assessment (Handheld).
findings:
Definitions
  • Varicose Veins: Dilated, tortuous superficial veins >3mm.
  • Saphena Varix: Dilation at SFJ, mimics femoral hernia but has venous hum + disappears on lying.
  • CEAP Classification: C1 (Spider), C2 (Varicose), C3 (Edema), C4 (Skin change), C5 (Healed ulcer), C6 (Active ulcer).
discussion:
Viva Questions

Indications for Surgery: Bleeding, Pain, Skin changes, Ulceration, Cosmesis.
Treatment Options:
1. Conservative (Stockings).
2. Endothermal Ablation (RFA/Laser) - Gold Standard.
3. Foam Sclerotherapy.
4. Open Surgery (High Tie & Strip).

name: Peripheral Arterial Disease
instruction: Examine the arterial system of the lower limbs.
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Skin: Pallor, Shiny hairless skin, Dystrophic nails.
  • Ulcers: Punched out, painful, pressure points (tips of toes/heel).
  • Gangrene: Dry (black/mummified) or Wet.
  • Buerger's Angle: Elevate leg to 45°. Note angle where pallor occurs (<20° = Severe ischemia).

2. Palpation

  • Temperature: Compare legs (coolness).
  • Capillary Refill: Normal <2s. Prolonged in ischemia.
  • Pulses:
    - Femoral: Mid-inguinal point.
    - Popliteal: Deep in fossa (flex knee 30°).
    - Posterior Tibial: Behind medial malleolus.
    - Dorsalis Pedis: Lateral to EHL tendon.

3. Auscultation

  • Bruits: Femoral, Aortic, Renal.
findings:
Signs of Ischemia
  • Acute (6 Ps): Pain, Pallor, Pulseless, Perishing cold, Paresthesia, Paralysis.
  • Chronic: Intermittent claudication, Rest pain (hanging leg out of bed), Tissue loss (ulcer/gangrene).
  • Leriche Syndrome: Aortoiliac occlusion -> Buttock claudication + Absent femoral pulses + Impotence.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Intermittent Claudication: Muscle pain on walking, relieved by rest. (Fixed claudication distance).
ABPI (Ankle Brachial Pressure Index):
- >0.9: Normal.
- 0.5 - 0.9: Claudication.
- <0.5: Critical Limb Ischemia.
- >1.3: Calcified vessels (Diabetics).
Management: Best medical therapy (Statin, Antiplatelet), Exercise, Angioplasty, Bypass.

name: Abdominal Mass
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Distension: 5 Fs (Fat, Fluid, Fetus, Flatus, Feces).
  • Scars: Kocher's, Midline, Paramedian.
  • Mass: Visible pulsation or movement with respiration.

2. Palpation

  • Superficial: Tenderness, guarding.
  • Deep: Identify mass. Assess: Site, Size, Edge, Surface, Consistency, Fixation, Pulsatility.
  • Organomegaly:
    - Liver: Start RIF, move up.
    - Spleen: Start RIF, move diagonal to LUQ. (Notch, inability to get above).
    - Kidney: Ballotable. Percussion note resonant (overlying bowel).

3. Percussion

  • Mass: Dull vs Resonant.
  • Shifting Dullness: Ascites.

4. Auscultation

  • Bowel Sounds: Obstruction vs Ileus.
  • Bruits: Renal/Aortic.
findings:
Mass Differentiation
  • Spleen: Moves inferomedially with inspiration, has a notch, cannot get above it, dull to percussion.
  • Kidney: Moves inferiorly, ballotable, resonant percussion (band of colonic resonance).
  • Liver: Moves inferiorly, cannot get above, dull.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Causes of Hepatomegaly:
- Smooth: CCF, Hepatitis, Fatty liver.
- Craggy: Metastases, HCC, Cirrhosis (sometimes).
Causes of Splenomegaly: Malaria, Portal Hypertension, Leukemia/Lymphoma, Hemolytic Anemia.
Murphy's Sign: Acute Cholecystitis.

name: Stoma Examination
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Site: LIF (Colostomy) vs RIF (Ileostomy).
  • Spout: Spouted (Ileostomy - protects skin) vs Flush (Colostomy).
  • Effluent: Liquid/Green (Ileum) vs Solid/Brown (Colon).
  • Skin: Excoriation, Herniation, Prolapse, Retraction.
  • Lumen: Single (End) vs Double (Loop).

2. Palpation

  • Stoma: Gently feel patency (digit).
  • Cough Impulse: Parastomal hernia.
  • Skin: Tenderness.

3. Conclusion

  • "I would like to examine the rectum and check the fluid chart."
findings:
Stoma Types
  • End Colostomy: LIF, Flush. After abdominoperineal resection (permanent) or Hartmann's (temporary).
  • Loop Ileostomy: RIF, Spouted. Defunctioning stoma to protect distal anastomosis.
  • Urostomy (Ileal Conduit): RIF, Spouted, Urine output.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Complications:
- Early: Necrosis (ischemia), Retraction, High output (dehydration).
- Late: Parastomal hernia, Prolapse, Stenosis, Skin irritation.
High Output Stoma: >1.5L/day. Mgmt: Restrict hypotonic fluids, Loperamide, PPI, Codeine.

name: Breast Lump
checklist:
1. Inspection (Position 1: Arms by side)

  • Symmetry: Size and shape.
  • Skin: Peau d'orange, dimpling, erythema, puckering.
  • Nipple: Inversion, discharge, eczema (Paget's), deviation.

2. Inspection (Dynamic)

  • Arms above head: Exposes tethering to pectoral fascia.
  • Hands on hips (push in): Contracts pectoralis major; accentuates dimpling.
  • Lean forward: Large breasts (pendulous).

3. Palpation (Lying flat, hand behind head)

  • Normal Breast: Use flat of hand, circular motion, all 4 quadrants + axillary tail.
  • The Lump: 3D's (Dimensions, Depth, Definition). Fixation to skin or muscle.
  • Nipple: Discharge?

4. Lymph Nodes (Sitting up)

  • Axillary: Central, Lateral, Pectoral, Subscapular, Apical.
  • Supraclavicular.
findings:
Differential Diagnosis
  • Fibroadenoma: 'Breast mouse', firm, highly mobile, painless, young women (<30).
  • Cyst: Smooth, fluid-filled, fluctuant, tender.
  • Carcinoma: Hard, irregular, tethered to skin/muscle, bloody discharge, lymphadenopathy.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Triple Assessment:
1. Clinical Examination.
2. Imaging (Mammogram >35y / USG <35y).
3. Pathology (Core Biopsy).
Peau d'orange: Cutaneous lymphatic edema due to blockage by cancer cells (simulates orange peel).

name: Surgical Lump (Lipoma/Cyst)
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Site: Anatomical location.
  • Skin: Punctum (Sebaceous cyst), Scars, Erythema, Pigmentation.
  • Shape/Size.

2. Palpation

  • Temperature/Tenderness.
  • Surface/Edge: Smooth vs Irregular. Well-defined vs Indistinct.
  • Consistency: Soft (Lipoma), Firm (Cyst/Node), Hard (Cancer/Bone).
  • Mobility: Fixation to skin (pinch test) or underlying muscle (contract muscle).
  • Fluctuance: Fluid filled (Paget's test).
  • Transillumination: Light glows through (Hydrocele/Lipoma sometimes).
  • Pulsatility: Aneurysm.

3. Auscultation

  • Bruit: AVM or Aneurysm.
findings:
Common Lumps
  • Lipoma: Soft, subcutaneous, lobulated, 'slipping sign', transilluminates (rarely).
  • Sebaceous Cyst: Firm, punctum present, fixed to skin, does not transilluminate.
  • Ganglion: Cystic, near joint/tendon, transilluminates.
  • Abscess: Red, Hot, Tender, Fluctuant.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Sebaceous Cyst vs Lipoma: Cyst has a punctum and is fixed to skin. Lipoma is subcutaneous (skin slides over it) and has a slipping edge.
Management: Excision biopsy (elliptical for cyst to include punctum).
Transillumination: Hydrocele, Epididymal cyst, Ganglion, Cystic hygroma.

name: Diabetic Foot Ulcer
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • General: Charcot deformity (rocker bottom), Claw toes, Callus.
  • Ulcer: Site (Planter/Heel/Toes), Edge (Punched out), Base (Granulation/Slough/Bone), Surround (Cellulitis).
  • Shoes: Inspect footwear for foreign bodies/wear.

2. Palpation

  • Temperature: Hot (Charcot/Infection) vs Cold (Ischemia).
  • Pulses: DP/PT.
  • Sensation: 10g Monofilament testing (Protective sensation). Vibration sense (tuning fork).

3. Probe

  • Probe-to-bone: If bone is palpable, osteomyelitis is likely.
findings:
Ulcer Types
  • Neuropathic: Painless, plantar aspect (pressure points), punched out, thick callus, warm foot, bounding pulses.
  • Neuroischemic: Painful (maybe), toes/heel, cool foot, absent pulses.
  • Venous: Gaiter area, shallow, sloping edge, hemosiderin staining.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Pathophysiology: Neuropathy (Motor = deformity, Sensory = trauma, Autonomic = dry skin) + Ischemia + Infection.
Charcot Arthropathy: Neuro-traumatic destruction of bones/joints. acute phase (Hot/Swollen) -> chronic (Deformity). Treatment: Total Contact Casting.

name: Carotid Arteries
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Neck: Scars (Endarterectomy), Pulsatile masses (Aneurysm/Tortuous vessel).
  • Eyes: Horner's syndrome (Ptosis, Miosis, Anhidrosis).

2. Palpation

  • Pulses: Common Carotid (anterior to SCM). Compare volume/character. Do NOT palpate both simultaneously.
  • Thrills: Palpable turbulence.

3. Auscultation

  • Bruits: Ask patient to hold breath. Listen at angle of jaw (bifurcation).

4. Neuro Exam

  • Brief Screen: Upper/Lower limb power and sensation (previous stroke).
findings:
Significance
  • Carotid Bruit: Turbulent flow. Usually implies >50% stenosis, but relationship to severity is poor (tight stenosis may be silent).
  • Amaurosis Fugax: "Curtain coming down" vision loss (emboli to ophthalmic artery).
discussion:
Viva Questions

Indication for CEA (Endarterectomy): Symptomatic stenosis >70% (NASCET trial).
Nerves at risk during surgery:
1. Hypoglossal (Tongue deviation).
2. Vagus (Voice).
3. Marginal Mandibular (Drooping mouth corner).
4. Glossopharyngeal.

name: Hand Examination
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Dorsum: Scars, swelling, deformities.
  • Palmar: Dupuytren's contracture (thickening), Thenar/Hypothenar wasting.
  • Nails: Pitting, Clubbing, Splinter hemorrhages.

2. Palpation

  • Temperature.
  • Pulses: Radial/Ulnar. Allen's Test.
  • Sensation:
    - Median: Index finger tip.
    - Ulnar: Little finger tip.
    - Radial: Dorsal web space.

3. Movement

  • Motor:
    - Median: "Make a bottle" (Abd Poll Brevis).
    - Ulnar: Cross fingers (Interossei).
    - Radial: Thumbs up/Wrist extension.

4. Special Tests

  • Carpal Tunnel: Phalen's (Flexion for 60s), Tinel's (Tap nerve).
  • Dupuytren's: Hueston's Table Top Test.
findings:
Common Conditions
  • Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Median nerve compression. Night pain, thenar wasting, sensory loss lateral 3.5 digits.
  • Dupuytren's: Fibromatosis of palmar fascia. Ring/Little finger flexion contracture. Risk: Alcohol, Diabetes, Genetics.
  • Trigger Finger: Stenosing tenosynovitis. Finger clicks/locks in flexion.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Anatomical Snuffbox: Floor is Scaphoid bone. Tenderness = Fracture.
Kanavel's Signs (Flexor Tenosynovitis):
1. Fusiform swelling.
2. Held in flexion.
3. Pain on passive extension.
4. Tenderness along sheath.

name: Neck Lump (Lymph Nodes)
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Site: Anterior vs Posterior triangle.
  • Skin: Erythema, sinus, punctum.

2. Palpation (Stand behind)

  • Levels I-VI:
    - I: Submental/Submandibular.
    - II-IV: Jugular chain (Upper/Mid/Lower).
    - V: Posterior Triangle.
    - VI: Anterior compartment (Thyroid).
  • Characteristics: Hard (Carcinoma), Rubbery (Lymphoma), Tender (Infection).
  • Fixation: To deep structures or skin.

3. Examination of Primary Sources

  • Scalp: Skin cancers.
  • Face/Ear.
  • Oral Cavity: Tongue/Tonsils.
  • Thyroid.
  • Abdomen: Virchow's Node (Left supraclavicular - Gastric/GI Ca).
findings:
Differential Diagnosis
  • Reactive: Tender, soft, recent infection.
  • Lymphoma: Rubbery, multiple, non-tender, hepato-splenomegaly.
  • Metastatic SCC: Hard, fixed, painless. Older patient + Smoking.
  • TB Adenitis: Matted, discharging sinus (Scrofula).
discussion:
Viva Questions

Rule of 80: In a non-thyroid neck lump in an adult >40: 80% are neoplastic, 80% of those are malignant, 80% of those are metastatic.
Investigation: FNAC (Cytology) first line. Panendoscopy (EUA) for unknown primary.

name: Scrotal Lump
checklist:
1. Inspection (Standing)

  • Skin: Ulcers, sinuses (TB), sebaceous cysts.
  • Asymmetry: Swelling.

2. Palpation

  • Get Above: If yes = Scrotal. If no = Hernia.
  • Testis: Palpate body. Hard/Irregular = Cancer. Sensation intact?
  • Epididymis: Posterior to testis. Cyst/Tenderness.
  • Cord: Vas deferens, Varicocele (bag of worms).

3. Special Tests

  • Transillumination:
    - Brilliant: Hydrocele / Epididymal Cyst.
    - Negative: Tumor / Hematocele / Hernia.
  • Cough Impulse: Hernia or Varicocele.
findings:
Differentiation
  • Hydrocele: Surrounds testis (cannot feel testis separately), transilluminates.
  • Epididymal Cyst: Separate from testis (posterior/superior), transilluminates.
  • Varicocele: 'Bag of worms', disappears lying down, cough impulse, usually Left side.
  • Testicular Tumor: Painless, hard, heavy, irregular lump arising from testis.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Varicocele & Renal Ca: Left gonadal vein drains to Left Renal Vein. Sudden onset L-Varicocele in older male = Renal Cell Carcinoma (tumor thrombus).
Tumor Markers: AFP, beta-HCG, LDH.

name: Chronic Liver Disease
instruction: Look for stigmata of chronic liver disease.
checklist:
1. Hands

  • Clubbing.
  • Leukonychia: White nails (Hypoalbuminemia).
  • Palmar Erythema: Red eminences (High estrogen).
  • Dupuytren's Contracture: Alcohol association.
  • Flapping Tremor: Asterixis (Encephalopathy).

2. Face

  • Eyes: Jaundice (sclera), Xanthelasma (PBC), Keyser-Fleischer rings (Wilson's).
  • Parotids: Enlarged (Alcohol).

3. Chest/Abdomen

  • Spider Naevi: SVC distribution. >5 is significant. Fill from center.
  • Gynecomastia: Loss of axillary hair.
  • Abdomen: Ascites, Caput Medusae, Hepatomegaly, Splenomegaly.
findings:
Causes of CLD
  • Alcohol.
  • Viral: Hep B, C.
  • Metabolic: NASH, Hemochromatosis (Bronze skin), Wilson's.
  • Autoimmune: PBC (Anti-Mitochondrial Ab), PSC (UC link).
discussion:
Viva Questions

Child-Pugh Score: Assessment of severity. (Bilirubin, Albumin, INR, Ascites, Encephalopathy).
Portal Hypertension Signs: Splenomegaly, Ascites, Varices (Esophageal/Caput Medusae), Hemorrhoids.

name: Facial Nerve (CN VII)
checklist:
1. Inspection

  • Resting Asymmetry: Drooping mouth corner, loss of nasolabial fold, smoothing of forehead wrinkles.
  • Ear: Vesicles (Ramsay Hunt), Scars (Parotidectomy).

2. Motor Function (Toes to Head)

  • Temporal: "Raise your eyebrows" (Sparing = UMN/Stroke. Loss = LMN/Bell's).
  • Zygomatic: "Close your eyes tightly" (Don't let me open them). Bell's phenomenon.
  • Buccal: "Blow out your cheeks" / "Show me your teeth".
  • Mandibular: "Pull down corners of mouth".
  • Cervical: Platysma grimace.

3. Special Tests

  • Taste: Anterior 2/3 tongue.
  • Hearing: Hyperacusis (Stapedius palsy).
findings:
LMN vs UMN
  • LMN (Bell's Palsy): Forehead is affected (cannot wrinkle). Whole hemiface paralysis.
  • UMN (Stroke): Forehead is spared (bilateral cortical innervation). Only lower quadrant paralysis.
discussion:
Viva Questions

Branches (Ten Zebras Bit My Cat): Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Marginal Mandibular, Cervical.
Parotid Surgery: Nerve runs through the gland. Damage leads to permanent palsy.
